repnme.cdata!:
Bangladesh - Shallow Tubewell and Low-lift
            Pump Irrigation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Shallow Tubewell and
            Low-lift Pump Irrigation Project for Bangladesh were as
            follows: International Development Association (IDA)
            performance was very good in providing the necessary
            assistance in sector studies and in promoting a detailed
            strategy of policy reform to be agreed between Government
            and the main donor agencies. Borrower performance was
            generally satisfactory. Some lessons learned included:
            projects which aim at de-regulation and liberalization
            should not impose additional restrictions which jeopardize
            achievement of the project's objectives; as conditions
            change, such as liberalized access of the private sector to
            foreign exchange, IDA should be alert to adjust projects
            more rapidly, projects based on careful sector and policy
            analysis and involving agreement on a policy strategy agreed
            by Government and major donors provide a good basis for
            making politically problematic policy reforms; continued
            commitment and vigilance is required to ensure, even where
            policy changes have been made in order to liberalize markets
            and encourage private sector development, that there is no
            piecemeal return to regulated markets in response to
            pressures for introduction of subsidies, duties, taxes and
            physical controls; and monitoring and evaluation proposals
            need to be detailed and focused and borrowers need to be
            convinced of the need for such activities.

repnme.cdata!:
Bangladesh - Shallow Tubewell and Low Lift
            Pump Irrigation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Shallow Tubewell and Low-lift Pump
            Irrigation Project's objectives are to increase
            agricultural production, income and employment by supporting
            increased investment by farmers in simple, low-cost minor
            irrigation equipment.  The equipment will be sold by private
            equipment dealers under the Government of Bangladesh's
            liberalized/deregulated policy framework for private
            sector-led minor irrigation development.  By providing a
            foreign exchange facility to allow private sector dealers to
            import small engines for shallow tubewells and low lift
            pumps, as well as power tillers, for sale to farmers, the
            project is expected to provide:  (a) irrigation for about
            340,000 ha of land using an estimated 75,000 shallow
            tubewells (STW); (b) irrigation for approximately 120,000 ha
            of land using some 6,000 low lift pumps (LLP); and (c)
            improved tillage for around 460,000 ha of land using about
            18,000 power tillers.  These numbers are indicative, since
            the actual types and quantities of equipment installed will
            depend on demand from farmers.  Support for these
            investments will be provided in the context of consolidating
            the existing policy framework for private sector-led minor
            irrigation development, and additional liberalization
            measures in the closely related areas of fertilizer
            distribution and foodgrain marketing.
